name: asimina-triloba
wildlife-value: Its flowers are pollinated by flies and beetles. Its fleshy fruits are eaten by songbirds, wild turkeys, squirrels, raccoons, opossums, black bears, and foxes. Pawpaws are larval host plants for the Zebra Swallowtail (Eurytides marcellus). The adult butterflies lay eggs in the north during two flights between April and August and in the south between March and December. Since adult Zebra Swallowtail butterflies also feed on flower nectar from milkweed, blueberries, blackberries, lilacs, redbuds, verbenas, and dogbane, consider adding these near pawpaws.
particularly-resistant-to-insects/diseas: Resistant to fire and moderately resistant to damage from deer.
edibility: Mature fruits have a banana custard flavor. Raw fruits can be eaten in small quantities but can cause stomach/skin irritation in some people.
light: Deep shade (Less than 2 hours to no direct sunlight)
Full sun (6 or more hours of direct sunlight a day)
Partial Shade (Direct sunlight only part of the day, 2-6 hours)
fruit-description: Edible fleshy fruit becomes soft and custard-like sweet taste similar to bananas, very nutritious. Glaucous surface.  Displays from August to October.  This plant needs a pollinizer plant to set fruit.
flower-description: Perfect (but self-incompatible). The burgundy flowers bloom in spring but are not showy. They are purplish brown with 6 petals and are 1 to 1.5 inches in diameter. They have a foul odor as they are pollinated by flies.
leaf-description: Alternate, simple, obovate to oblong 6-12 inches long 2-3 inches wide with a green pepper odor when crushed.  The leaves are in two ranks and hang pendulously from the stem.  The leaf underside is pale and glaucous.
bark-description: Smooth, brown splotched with wart-like lenticels.  Becomes fissured and scaly with age.
stem-description: Buds are pubescent with no scales.  Young buds and stems are cinnamon brown.
poison-symptoms: Stomach and intestinal pain from eating the fruit skin or seeds. Skin irritation from handling fruit.
